Polymers such as plastics, coming from the petrochemical industry, are a very important part of the economy around the world as they have shown potential in many domestic and industrial applications (Bhatia et al.
Bakelite is the first synthetic plastic produced in 1907 which marked the onset of the plastic industry, although production did not reach major levels until the 1950s (Worm et al.
Napper and Thompson 2020).

The plastic industry manufactured approximately 8300 million metric tonnes of plastic from 1950 to 2018, and the production is still elevating at an annual rate of 5%, reaching 368 million metric tonnes in 2019 (annually), and is forecasted to reach 1100 million tonnes by 2050 (UN Environment Programme 2018;
Kannan and Vimalkumar 2021;
Rosenboom et al.

Along with the mass production of single-use and disposable plastic materials, the consequence of the increasing quantity of plastic waste was first realized in the 1970s as a result of growing consumption.
For example, in the case of the food industry, food products are regularly packed and vended, so the amount of waste generated at food outlets is huge.
Plastic packaging materials, after serving the purpose, enter into the group of post-consumer waste which further finds a way to recycling, incineration, and landfilling (Ncube et al.
It was estimated that around 76% of the total plastic produced globally ends up as garbage and the remaining might exist as an in-use stock (Geyer et al.
Ali et al.
Out of the total waste generated, 9% is recycled, 12% is burnt, and the remaining 79% is landfilled or discharged into the environment (Ali et al.
Such improper disposal leads to physical interactions of plastics with the wider ecosystem, majorly affecting human health (Ali et al.
There are various plastic types used in healthcare, electronics, everyday devices, and transportation, with 50% of them intended for single use only (Hopewell et al.
The most recent increment in the percentage of plastic waste generation and accumulation is due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Since the pandemic began, plastic garbage has been generated at a pace of 1.
6 million tonnes per day (Benson et al.
It was also estimated that during the pandemic, 3.

4 billion single-use face shields and facemasks were disposed of globally every day, and 585 million tonnes (approximately) of plastic waste was generated around the globe at the end of the year 2020, significantly contributing to plastic pollution (Benson et al.
Agricultural plastics disposed of in the environment also pose a severe danger to human and ecosystem health.

According to the data shared by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations in the report “Assessment of agricultural plastics and their sustainability: a call for action, 2021,” agriculture value chains used 12.
5 million tonnes of plastic products each year, where crop and livestock, fisheries and aquaculture, and forestry account for annual usage of 10.
2 million tonnes, 2.
1 million tonnes, and 0.
2 million tonnes, respectively (FAO News and Media 2021).
Plastic is just a combination of the base polymer and diverse additives or chemicals.
Due to their resistant chemical configurations, plastics tend to decompose slowly, causing high environmental pollution (Walker et al.
According to some researchers, identifying and managing chemicals in plastics are key to tackling plastic waste (Mehta 2023).
All these compounds are added to achieve desired improvements and modulation of the material properties, but they all affect recycling and pose major health risks to humans (Hahladakis et al.
Mehta 2023).
During recycling, if the composition to sort is unknown, the waste is mixed and a whole new set of unmanageable additives is generated, creating new risks (Mehta 2023).

Plastics like polyvinyl chloride (PVC), polystyrene (PS), polyurethane (PU), and polycarbonate (PC) contain harmful monomers and additives such as functional additives like heat stabilizers, plasticizers (diisobutyl phthalate, phthalic esters, etc.)
, foaming agents, and slip agents (fatty acid amides and esters, wax, etc.)
colorants (pigments, azo colorants);
fillers like mica, clay, barium sulfate, and calcium carbonate;
and reinforcements like glass and carbon fibers (Hahladakis et al.

Other than these, residual and unreacted monomers like styrene and vinyl chloride monomers are also present which are considered carcinogenic to humans and, therefore, the packaging materials contacting food must not contain vinyl chloride monomers of more than 1 mg kg−1 (Worm et al.
Hahladakis et al.
Such monomers present in food packaging materials can drift into the food items and, after a certain limit, can be absorbed by the human body (Hahladakis et al.
Monomers like bisphenol A diglyceride ether (BADGE), present in food containers, are found to cause faster cell division and can also cause cytotoxicity in living tissues.
Bisphenol A (BPA) is a known endocrine disruptor (EDC) used in polycarbonate bottles, cans, plastic containers, and other food containers (Hahladakis et al.
Being a hormone disruptor, BPA has been shown to have adverse effects on reproductive hormones in animal models (Konieczna et al.
Fetuses and babies are found to be more vulnerable because hormones play a significant role in their development (Hahladakis et al.
There is a relationship between BPA levels and metabolic diseases like type II diabetes and insulin resistance, obesity, hypertension, and liver diseases (Wang and Qian 2021).

Other substances like phthalates and adipates are common plasticizers that possess hormone-like properties and are frequently added to brittle plastics like PVC to make them pliable for use in food packaging, toys, and other daily items (Worm et al.
It is reported that phthalates leach into foods and beverages consumed by humans, especially when heated.
These are used to make soft and flexible plastics like blood bags and tubing, toys, and car interiors (Gaston and Tulve 2019).
Exposure to phthalates during pregnancy may have a negative impact on the health of the baby and the birth process (Chen et al.

During an investigation related to maternal phthalate exposure using cord blood, genome-wide DNA methylation profiling of infants was conducted and it was discovered that DNA methylation of genes involved in spermatogenesis, androgen response, and cancer-related pathways is epigenetically affected by prenatal phthalate exposure.
Of all the phthalates, diethylhexyl phthalate (DEHP) is the most commonly tested and has the highest concentration in food (Wang and Qian 2021).
It is difficult to conclude which compound has higher migration potential because the amount migrating into food is determined by its initial concentration added to the product.
Furthermore, the nature of the food, food-additive interactions, and storage conditions can all have a major impact on the overall migration mechanism of the additive (Hahladakis et al.

Other substances such as toxic metals, brominated flame retardants (BFR), persistent organic pollutants (POP), and polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), commonly known as potentially toxic substances (PoTSs), could be released into the environment during the recycling process.

The negative impacts of such compounds are imposed at all phases of the life cycle of a plastic material (use, disposal, recovery, and recycling), presenting a need for substitution with more sustainable or biobased materials (Hahladakis et al.
Other than the human population, plastic pollution is greatly affecting terrestrial ecosystems with the release of PoTSs in the soil and groundwater.
Deposition of such chemicals at the surface of soil compromises soil’s foremost roles of sustaining biodiversity, and moderating nutrient cycling.
As soil is a viable route to groundwater, these chemicals may eventually enter the groundwater systems through leaching, hence contaminating it and, in turn, reaching humans (Hahladakis et al.
Chia et al.
There is also an apparent predominance of plastics in marine litter, accounting for 60 to 80% of marine debris worldwide (Deshpande et al.
Every year, between 4.
8 and 12.
7 million tons of plastic waste are dumped into the ocean (Deshpande et al.

Especially, plastic fragments of size smaller than 5 mm, known as microplastics having biomagnification and bioaccumulation potency, float on the sea surface and become an easy target for animals from fish to sea birds, thus easily entering the marine food chain (Kumar et al.

Such massive production and consumption of plastic materials is directly responsible for fossil fuel depletion and the management of huge amounts of waste generated to safeguard the members of the ecosystem is a significant yet tough part of plastic’s life cycle.

The process of recycling, the most common and easiest approach for plastic waste management, provides a sustainable source of raw materials for industries, significantly reducing the impact (particularly CO2 pollution) of plastic products on the environment (Hopewell et al.
As shown in Fig.
1, out of the 9% of the total plastic waste entering recycling, only 2% enters closed-loop recycling and some is lost during the process (Ali et al.

Primarily, more focus and improvement are needed in the field of recycling to benefit in terms of reducing pollution levels, less energy consumption, natural resource allocation, saving landfill space, reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and economic benefits (Miguel et al.
According to the European Union (EU), in 2018, Europe alone collected 29.
1 million metric tonnes of plastic waste, out of which 9.
3 million metric tonnes was recycled and 7.
2 million metric tonnes was disposed of at landfill sites (Nandy et al.
Landfilling is associated with drawbacks like the generation of toxic leachates, soil infertility, groundwater contamination, and water supply contamination (Saldıvar and Vivaldo 2013).
Further, plastic production and the incineration of plastic waste are responsible for an estimated 400 metric tons of CO2 emissions per year (Tuladhar and Yin 2019).
Figure 1 shows the fate of plastic waste generated and the way current practices of plastic waste disposal affect the environment.

Although encouraging proper recycling processes can help in managing plastic waste to some extent, this alone cannot lead to a significant improvement in the current situation.

Therefore, recycling along with other strategies like biodegradation using microbial enzymes and the use of biobased or biodegradable plastics instead of petro-based conventional plastic material can synergistically cause a huge and significant difference in the field of plastic production and plastic waste management.
The review significantly provides current statistics on plastic production, and plastic waste generation and management.
This information can help to forecast future developments and adapt strategies accordingly in this sector.
The review reveals the effectiveness of current waste management practices like recycling and identifies areas for improvement to mitigate environmental issues caused by plastic pollution.
It further suggests biological approaches like biodegradation for managing already existing plastic waste.

Later, it describes biobased biodegradable plastics as an alternative to traditional plastics and explains how adapting to such biobased materials can be sustainable at the production and end-of-life phase of a plastic product.
Overall, this review will significantly serve as a database for researchers working in the sector of plastic pollution, plastic waste management, and biobased plastics.
A comprehensive review of the literature was undertaken, utilizing several online database sources such as Google Scholar, PubMed, ResearchGate, Springer Nature, and Science Direct.
Several data-related websites were also accessed and referred.
The primary focus of this review is plastic pollution and its possible remediation.

The most frequently used keywords were “plastic pollution and waste management,” “Recycling as potential plastic waste management strategy,” “Polyethylene terephthalate,” “Biodegradation,” “PET biocatalyst,” “Biocatalyst production tools for plastic degradation,” “Potential microbes for plastic degradation,” “Bioplastics,” “European Bioplastics,” and “Potential microbes for bioplastic production.
” The review mostly includes papers from the time frame of 2013 to 2023.
It also includes some old studies to validate the existence of plastic pollution for decades.

Recycling is an efficient approach to waste management that can lower the need for new or primary raw materials, minimize pollution caused by raw material extraction, contribute to energy recovery, and also help reduce waste in landfills (Huang et al.
Plastic waste recycling can lead to the reduction of the environmental footprint during the production process, as well as during the end-use treatment or disposal process.
Different methods of recycling plastic materials exist, and the efficiency of the processes varies depending on the polymer type, package design, and product category (Hopewell et al.
Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) occupies 7.
7% of the European market and is the third most-used polymer in the packaging industry accounting for 16% of European consumption (Nisticò 2020).
Such widespread consumption and disposal made PET one of the most recycled polymer types (Hopewell et al.
Currently, a very small fraction of plastic waste is recycled, mostly through mechanical recycling (Santagata et al.

Mechanical recycling is presently the only plastic waste recycling option that involves processing and recirculation of plastic waste without significantly changing the chemical structure of the material (van der Hulst et al.
This approach of considering post-consumer waste as raw material for developing new products promotes the concept of a circular economy (Santagata et al.

Separating plastics into completely homogenous streams and the lack of infrastructure for the collection and sorting of different plastic wastes restrict the deployment of the mechanical recycling process.

The failure to achieve complete separation of plastic waste results in a mix of different types of plastic in the final recycled product, also affecting the physical properties of the final product, hence reducing the quality (Davidson et al.
Therefore, new recycling approaches are developed to provide solutions for plastic waste that is currently not recirculated (van der Hulst et al.
Chemical recycling is one of those novel techniques aimed at converting waste into valuable products (Santagata et al.
This can be done by converting polymers to monomers or into a liquid or gaseous mixture of chemicals that can be utilized as raw material for plastic production (van der Hulst et al.

Therefore, the final material obtained after chemical recycling has the potential to substitute resins derived directly from natural gas or crude oil, thus decreasing reliance on non-renewable resources (Davidson et al.

Depending on the type of plastic waste, there are various chemical recycling processes, including gasification, pyrolysis, solvolysis, and depolymerization that break down the plastic waste into monomers for making new plastics (Jiang et al.
Other than economic infeasibility, several technical challenges hinder waste processing through traditional methods (Qureshi et al.
It is seen that after a certain number of recycling cycles, the plastic will start to lose its properties, making it unsuitable for reuse (Zhang et al.
Plastic products like multilayer materials and the use of diverse additives to manufacture plastics make the recycling process more complex.
The post-consumer waste stream is also usually contaminated with materials like organic waste, metals, food, wood, and glass, making it unsuitable for mechanical recycling.
Such contaminated waste is then directed toward incineration and landfilling (Qureshi et al.
The processing of such non-recyclable products, existing in the environment for an extended period, requires high energy input and advanced infrastructure.
This need can be met using microbial and enzymatic degradation technologies (Zhang et al.
Therefore, bioprocessing of biocatalysts and biotechnological methods are found to be suitable for improving plastic waste degradation (Mohanan et al.

Using a framework for improving biocatalyst production, boosting enzyme activity by using metal ions, enzyme immobilization, and efforts applied in the field of protein engineering to implement techniques like mutagenesis might help in achieving the goal of plastic waste degradation, thus reducing its amount from the environment (Mohanan et al.

Along with this, biobased and biodegradable plastics are being explored as a substitute for conventional plastics by preserving the beneficial and significant material properties of petro-based plastics, allowing for a shift toward a circular economy, reduced extraction and usage of fossil fuel, and reduced environmental burdens arising at end-of-life (Bishop et al.
Microbial decomposition or degradation of plastic waste is a cost-effective and environmentally sustainable method that can be implemented through microbial cultivation or microbial enzyme actions.
The process of microbial degradation of plastics can be done via composting.
Although the number of composting facilities is limited, developments are seen for conducting more effective degradation of plastic waste at composting facilities.
Composting is carried out by microorganisms that break down carbon-based polymers into organic matter (food source), CO2 (by-product), and humus, a soil nutrient (end product).
It offers a cost-effective approach and a “cradle to grave” option that returns carbon to the environment as CO2 or fertilizer.
The rate of degradation via composting can be optimized at high temperatures under aerobic conditions (Lim and Thian 2022).

Microbes acquire certain enzymes that allow them to utilize plastics as substrates by catalyzing the oxidation–reduction reaction to break down the chemical bonds in the plastic polymers, hence leading to plastic degradation (Jaiswal et al.
In recent times, the idea of using single or mixed microbial cultures which are genetically modified to perform enzymatic degradation of plastics has also been proposed at composting facilities.
Further, the adoption of biodegradable plastics will also support the degradation process (Lim and Thian 2022).
For microbial biodegradation, the characteristics of biodegradable compounds, such as their chemical composition, age, production and processing techniques, and application conditions, are crucial.

The physical and chemical features of a polymer that determine its biodegradability include hydrophobicity/hydrophilicity, crystallinity, molecular weight and density, surface topology, and pliability of the polymer chain (Mohanan et al.
Samak et al.

The surface hydrophilicity of plastics makes them a suitable material for microbial biofilms to grow on their surface and later use them as a source of carbon and energy, hence accelerating the deterioration process.
Compared to aromatic polyesters, aliphatic polyesters have higher biodegradation efficiency (Samak et al.
Other than the physicochemical properties of the polymer, the rate of the biodegradation process also relies on several abiotic factors like UV light and oxidizing agents.
Some microorganisms, including bacteria and fungi (e.
g., Aspergillus sp.
, Bacillus sp.
, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Chaetomium sp.
, Fusarium sp.
, Penicillium sp.)
, have been found to degrade petroleum-based polymers in vitro (Mohanan et al.
PET is an aromatic synthetic polyester that carries useful material properties such as low weight and good mechanical durability.
It is therefore widely used in the beverages and food industries as a packaging material and represents 10% of the plastic market share (Barth et al.
Ali et al.
Recent advances have created a possibility to degrade PET through the enzymatic action of particular microbes or genetically modified microbes or directly the enzymes (Nisticò 2020).
As described further, many studies on PET biodegradation using pure and mixed microbial communities proved the existence of this process.
A study done by Yoshida et al.
(2016) revealed that Ideonella sakaiensis 201-F6, isolated from a PET-exposed environment, can degrade PET by adhering to its surface and using it as an energy and carbon source.
During the study, it was found that this bacterium can produce two enzymes, heat liable PET hydrolase (known as PETase) and MHET hydrolase (MHETase).

MHETase and PETase hydrolyze mono-(2-hydroxyethyl) terephthalic acid and polyethylene terephthalic acid, respectively, into terephthalic acid (TPA) and ethylene glycol (EG) monomers which are not harmful to the environment (Yoshida et al.
A combined chemo-enzymatic hydrolysis approach for the breakdown of PET into TPA and EG (monomeric form) is described in Fig.
2 (depicting the detailed pathway of PET biodegradation).
This method is promising for obtaining TPA with 97% purity in an eco-friendly manner without involving harsh chemicals for the pre-treatment (Quartinello et al.

A 50% weight loss in post-consumer PET food packaging containers was achieved at 70 °C after 96 h of reaction in a scaled-up enzyme reactor with TfCut2 (Wei et al.

The idea of exploiting model organisms for the over-expression of commercial enzymes has recently been implemented successfully and demonstrated to be a cost-effective approach.
Easy handling and easy genetic manipulation of Escherichia coli (E.
coli) make it the most wanted fermentative bacterium for the large-scale production of the biocatalyst.
With a high cell density, the process of recombinant protein production in E.

E.

It also provides valuable insight into the mechanism of decomposition and substrate affinity for PET (Samak et al.
Cbotu_EstA and Cbotu_EstB are two novel esterases found in Clostridium botulinum which were expressed in E.
coli and were found to hydrolyze poly(butylene adipate-co-butylene terephthalate) (PBAT), a biodegradable polyester (Perz et al.
Most significantly, among all PET-degrading enzymes identified to date, PETase from Ideonella sakaiensis (IsPETase) has the highest PET degradation activity (Son et al.
However, poor thermal stability somewhere limits its potential for PET degradation.
Son et al.

(2019) developed a rational protein engineering technique by employing structural data on IsPETase and examined numerous IsPETase variants for high thermal stability to increase PET degradation activity.

In comparison to IsPETaseWT (wild type), the IsPETaseS121E/D186H/R280A variant, engineered for having a stabilized β6–β7 connecting loop and expanded subsite IIc, had a Tm value that was increased by 8.
81 °C and PET degradation activity that was elevated by 14-fold at 40 °C (Son et al.

Circular economy attempts to imitate the loop-closing characteristic of nature in manmade systems by using old goods as secondary raw materials resulting in improved raw material availability, reduced environmental impacts, and improved economic growth.

2018NatureWorks | Composting 2022 Mechanical recycling, landfilling, and incineration are the three most used methods for plastic waste management around the globe, but there are several challenges associated with these approaches.
Although recommended for energy recovery, the serious concern with incineration as a plastic waste management strategy is the generation of harmful furans and dioxins during the process.
With ineffective and defective methods and minimal air pollution monitoring equipment, the issue is getting worse.
However, the application of the best available capture techniques can help to mitigate this problem.
In 2015, the incineration of plastic waste alone produced 16 million tonnes of greenhouse emissions.
By 2030 and 2050, respectively, the number is expected to reach 49 million metric tonnes and 91 million metric tonnes (Vanapalli et al.
The CO2 emissions from landfilling are negligible in comparison to incineration.

Although landfilling stands at the bottom of the waste management hierarchy, it is still more prevalent because it is found to cause fewer CO2 emissions than incineration for non-biodegradable plastics (Eriksson and Finnveden 2009).
To determine such data for biobased or biodegradable plastics, various sustainability assessments are still needed on a global scale (Spierling et al.

Improper waste segregation and its disposal are practiced in the majority of developing and underdeveloped regions, causing significant space constraints, and leaching of hazardous chemicals and air pollutants from the mixture of waste materials (Vanapalli et al.
Various techno-economic analyses (TEA) and LCA (life cycle assessment) are used to evaluate the costs and environmental impacts of a product (Uekert et al.

According to the LCA studies, out of all the waste management strategies, recycling was found to be the most efficient plastic waste management strategy, resulting in net energy savings, a net reduction in the release of harmful gases, and less human toxicity (Hahladakis and Iacovidou 2019).

Although mechanical recycling is possibly the most common method for recycling plastic waste, it is always associated with obstacles like the presence of additives and inorganic impurities, cross-contamination of polymers leading to differences in melting points and processing temperatures, improper segregation at the source or during collection, and incomplete polymer degradation (Vanapalli et al.
PET, having minimal impurities, is the most recycled plastic type with an 80% recycling rate (Vanapalli et al.

However, this is not the case with all types of plastic materials, especially single-use plastics and multi-layered plastics that have high processing costs, technical constraints, and poor integral structure.

Chemical recycling is gaining much attention in recent times, but it is also likely to face limitations such as the need for pure feedstock, standard sorted or reprocessed plastic waste, and a lack of complete information on environmental and health impacts (Hopewell et al.

Post-consumer plastic covers the biggest fraction of plastic packaging waste and is the most tedious to deal with as it comprises mixed polymer wastes with many organic and inorganic impurities (Vanapalli et al.
The environmental and health impacts of such mixed plastic waste need to be studied.
Therefore, simplifying these mixtures is a key challenge.
However, coordination along the supply chains is necessary to achieve circularity.
The industry players and the recyclers need to set some design principles, i.
e., designing the product in a better way, and keeping the material’s end-of-life option in mind (Mehta 2023).
For a proper and smooth recycling process, consumers also play an important role.
Their purchasing decisions, perceptions, behavior, and attitudes toward the use and disposal of plastics are also challenging (Hahladakis and Iacovidou 2019).

The national policies of the government on plastic waste management are lined with the approach of 3R (Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle) and on the policy statement “Vistas of Prosperity,” as well as the view (as stated in “Sustainable Environmental Policy”) that “The linear economy in which manufacturers produce goods using the existing raw materials and dispose of waste into the environment will be replaced with the circular economy in which waste in one industry can be used as raw material in another (Re-Use, Recycle, Re-Purpose).
” The policies also state that along with the 3R approach, work toward “Zero Landfill” is also important.

A key activity of the plan is to facilitate the collection of segregated plastic waste and recycling of plastic waste as a profitable business to produce quality raw materials for the plastic industry.
These policies provide a regulatory framework that guides stakeholders toward more responsible consumption, production, and disposal of plastic materials (Ministry of Environment 2021).
However, unawareness and ignorance toward these policies from producers and consumers have led to mismanaged plastic production and waste management.
Other than the conventional methods, as in the existing policy, biodegradation and biobased alternatives can also play a critical role in plastic waste management.
Bacteria have been extensively studied for plastic degradation.
However, bacterial degradation of plastic material is not proven to be an efficient approach in all environments.

For example, Ideonella sakaiensis, having the ability to produce PETase enzyme, is not able to adapt to the marine environment where most of the plastic waste gathers, whereas several non-hazardous algal species from Bacillariophyceae, Chlorophyceae, and Cyanophyceae were able to form biofilms on polythene surfaces inside several contaminated water sources like lakes, ponds, and wastewater (Ali et al.

It was also found that cyanobacterial species like Phormidium lucidum and Oscillatoria subbrevis can reduce the lamellar thickness, weight, and crystallinity of PE carry bags without the use of pro-oxidant additives or pretreatment (Sarmah and Rout 2018).
Algal biodegradation is neither dependent on any specific pretreatment step nor a rich carbon source, thus can be considered a better approach when compared to bacterial degradation (Ali et al.

To further explore the mechanism involved in the microbial degradation of plastics, metagenomic and proteomic approaches are taken into consideration which can help to improve microbial enzyme activity and performance (thermostability, substrate binding capacity, etc.)

Although microbial enzyme or free-enzyme mediated biocatalytic depolymerization of plastic material is seen as a nature-friendly alternative to conventional plastic treatment methods, several challenges limit its potential.
To accurately identify a plastic-degrading enzyme from a wide metagenomic library is a major challenge as current identification methods are less sensitive and have low throughput.
Therefore, high-throughput screening methods are required.
From an economical point of view, an enzyme biocatalysis system is also hard to maintain at a large scale due to a shorter enzyme lifetime and complicated enzyme recovery and reuse.
However, the identification and genetic manipulation of plastic-degrading microbes hold great potential.
However, the use of such microbial enzyme–based techniques for plastic degradation should be applicable after a proper risk assessment of the process (Zhu et al.

The major reason behind the limited production and consumption of such material is its high production costs further leading to its high market value.

Uncontrolled and mismanaged production, use, and disposal of non-biodegradable, petroleum-based plastic products are causing severe environmental issues.
It is very important to improve the existing solutions like recycling and adapt to them as a regular and consistent practice.
For this, government and international bodies should prioritize circular economy principles.
Policies focusing on circularity will encourage plastic-producing companies to carefully evaluate all steps of their product’s expected life cycle and disposal method.
This can help consumers to choose more sustainable materials over conventional plastics.
At the same time, it is crucial to find effective ways for the degradation of existing plastic waste.
Biodegradation of plastic waste through biocatalytic tools can help in the safe eradication of already accumulated as well as continuously accumulating plastic trash.
The problem of plastic pollution needs to be understood at both the producer’s and consumer’s levels.

By promoting the production and use of biobased and biodegradable plastics, the current end-of-life scenario can be improved in terms of environmental sustainability and the burden of plastic pollution on the environment can be reduced.

Overall, the present review highlights the current situation of plastic pollution, by discussing the environmental impacts caused by the increasing problem of plastic waste generation and accumulation, current waste management approaches, and a comparison between their efficiencies for managing plastic waste, where recycling was found to be the most efficient of all.

Recycling properly and disposing of wast.title: The World's Plastic Pollution Crisis Explained
content: The World's Plastic Pollution Crisis Explained
Much of the planet is swimming in discarded plastic, which is harming animal and possibly human health.
Can it be cleaned up?
5 - 8 Conservation Image While plastic pollution is a worldwide problem it is most obvious聽in less-wealthy African and Asian聽nations, like the Philippines.
Here,聽children play among plastic waste on the shore of Manila Bay.
Plastic pollution has become one of the most pressing environmental issues, as rapidly increasing production of disposable plastic products overwhelms the world鈥檚 ability to deal with them.
Plastic pollution is most visible in less-wealthy Asian and African nations, where garbage collection systems are often inefficient or nonexistent.
But wealthy nations, especially those with low recycling rates, also have trouble properly collecting discarded plastics.
Plastic trash has become so ubiquitous it has prompted efforts to write a global treaty negotiated by the United Nations.
How Did this Happen?
Plastics made from fossil fuels are just over a century old.
Production and development of thousands of new plastic products accelerated after World War II to the extent that life without plastics would be unimaginable today.

Plastics revolutionized medicine with life-saving devices, made space travel possible, lightened cars and jets鈥攕aving fuel and lessening pollution鈥攁nd saved lives with helmets, incubators, and equipment for clean drinking water.
The conveniences plastics offer, however, led to a throw-away culture that reveals the material鈥檚 dark side: Today, single-use plastics account for 40 percent of the plastic produced every year.
Many of these products, such as plastic bags and food wrappers, are used for mere minutes to hours, yet they may persist in the environment for hundreds of years.
Plastics by the NumbersSome key facts: How Plastics Move around the WorldMost of the plastic trash in the oceans, Earth鈥檚 last sink, flows from land.
Trash is also carried to sea by聽major rivers, which act as conveyor belts, picking up more and more trash as they move downstream.
Once at sea, much of the plastic trash remains in coastal waters.
But once caught up in ocean currents, it can be transported around the world.

On聽Henderson Island, an uninhabited atoll in the Pitcairn Group isolated halfway between Chile and New Zealand, scientists found plastic items from Russia, the United States, Europe, South America, Japan, and China.
They were carried to the South Pacific by the South Pacific gyre, a circular ocean current.
MicroplasticsOnce at sea, sunlight, wind, and wave action break down plastic waste into small particles, often less than half a centimer (one-fifth of an inch) across.
These so-called microplastics are spread throughout the water column and have been found in every corner of the globe, from Mount Everest, the highest peak, to the聽Mariana Trench, the deepest trough.
Microplastics are breaking down further into smaller and smaller pieces.
Plastic microfibers (or the even smaller nanofibers), meanwhile, have been found in municipal drinking water systems and drifting through the聽air.

Harm to WildlifeMillions of animals are killed by plastics every year, from birds to fish to other marine organisms. Nearly 700 species, including endangered ones, are known to have been affected by plastics.
Nearly every species of seabird eats plastics.
Most of the deaths to animals are caused by entanglement or starvation.
Seals,聽whales, turtles, and other animals are strangled by聽abandoned fishing gear聽or discarded聽six-pack rings.
Microplastics have been聽found聽in more than 100 aquatic species, including fish, shrimp, and mussels destined for our dinner plates.
In many cases, these tiny bits pass through the digestive system and are expelled without consequence.
But plastics have also been found to have blocked digestive tracts or pierced organs, causing death.
Stomachs so packed with plastics reduce the urge to eat, causing starvation.
Plastics have been consumed by land-based animals, including elephants, hyenas, zebras, tigers, camels, cattle, and other large mammals, in some cases聽causing death.
Tests have also confirmed liver and cell damage and disruptions to聽reproductive systems,聽prompting some species, such as聽oysters,聽to produce fewer eggs.
New research shows that聽larval fish are eating nanofibers聽in the first days of life, raising new questions about the effects of plastics on fish populations.
Stemming the Plastic Tide Once in the ocean, it is difficult鈥攊f not impossible鈥攖o retrieve plastic waste.
Mechanical systems, such as聽Mr.
Trash Wheel, a litter interceptor in Maryland鈥檚 Baltimore Harbor, can be effective at picking up large pieces of plastic, such as foam cups and food containers, from inland waters.
But once plastics break down into microplastics and drift throughout the water column in the open ocean, they are virtually impossible to recover.
The solution is to prevent plastic waste from entering rivers and seas in the first place, many scientists and conservationists鈥攊ncluding the聽National Geographic Society鈥攕ay.

This could be accomplished with improved waste management systems and聽recycling, better product design that takes into account the short life of disposable packaging, and reduction in manufacturing of unnecessary single-use plastics.

org/ocean-cleaning-organizations/ The ocean is the life support system of our planet, and the way we treat it will have repercussions on all life on Earth for the years to come.
Unfortunately, over the last decade, we had to come to terms with the fact that its resources are not limitless, and its vastness is not immune to human impact.
For example, an enormous amount of pollution enters the waterways every day, ending up in the ocean and forming the infamous garbage patches in the center of the ocean’s currents (gyres).
This and other issues like oil spills, aquaculture, unregulated fishing and maritime transport are threatening the wellbeing and preservation of our ocean.

Scientists are telling us that the time has come to take responsibility and safeguard the ocean, and many individuals all over the world have stepped up to face these problems, working hard every day to ensure the ocean and its ecosystems are protected.

In this article, we will look at all the amazing organizations that make the best of people’s skills and expertise for saving our seas and making a difference in the creation of a more sustainable future.
Below, you will find some of the most inspirational ocean companies that are working hard to reduce ocean pollution, protecting marine ecosystems, and saving our seas for future generations.
The Ocean Conservancy is one of the oldest organizations dedicated to the safeguarding of our ocean.
Bill Kardash originally founded it in 1972 and its main mission was to educate people to care about animals and the environment.
The organization fought for individual species, but then realized that to protect species, we must also protect their habitats, and it was renamed The Ocean Conservancy in 2001.
Nowadays, this incredible organizations works all around the world to protect the ocean, its ecosystems and inhabitants, and the communities who depend on it.
The Ocean Conservancy works in a wide range of sectors, from fighting climate change to helping develop and implement better government policies, to implementing sustainable fishing practices.
They bring science, community and policy together to find innovative solutions for a more sustainable future.
The Ocean Cleanup is a non-profit foundation founded by Dutch inventor Boyan Slat in 2013, and it has since been battling against plastic pollution in our oceans.

It does this by developing new technologies to remove plastic debris from marine ecosystems, which will improve our planet’s environmental issues, the global economy and the health of human beings and wildlife.

By removing plastic from the ocean with the latest technologies, they prevent it breaking down into dangerous microplastics and, by working in rivers, they intercept ocean-bound plastic and prevent it from entering coastal waters in the first place.
The Ocean Cleanup aims at cleaning up to 90% of floating ocean plastic by 2040.
Clean Ocean Action works on the Eastern coast of the United States of America to improve and protect the quality of marine waters.
It uses science, law, research, education and community engagement to protect the national and regional waterways.
The organization consists of a coalition of groups working together since 1984, named the “Ocean Wavemakers”.
After COA’s staff has researched the threats and decided on a policy to implement, these groups collaborate and use their individual experience and skills to bring change to the real world.
For the past 30+ years, the organization has been organizing press events and rallies, testifying at public hearings and distributing literature to empower citizens to protect the ocean.
As you can understand by the name, this organization works to protect and save coral reefs around the world and it is one of the biggest NGOs focusing exclusively on this goal.
CORAL works at local, regional and global levels, connecting to coastal communities and using innovative science and technologies.
They also are at the forefront of new research focusing on how corals adapt to the changing ocean conditions we have been experiencing in the last few decades.
This research has shown that corals can actually adapt to climate change, and that there is hope that we will be able to save coral reefs for generations to come.

The Sea Life Trust is a registered charity organization that works to protect the planet’s oceans, their wildlife and ecosystems. They support local projects to safeguard marine wildlife and their habitats, as well as working on conservation campaigns on a global level.

One of their main aim is to work on reducing plastic pollution by creating campaigns and supporting cleanup projects all around the world, as well as removing ghost-fishing gear, one of the greatest killers in our ocean.
They also own and operate two marine wildlife sanctuaries: the Beluga Whale Sanctuary, off the coast of Iceland, and the Cornish Seal Sanctuary, in the UK.
The Surfrider Foundation is made up of a powerful activist community and network that works and volunteers for the protection and enjoyment of the world’s ocean, waves and beaches.
You can join this organization by becoming a volunteer, donating or taking action directly from your computer, for example contacting your local officials.
The Foundation was born in the 80s in Malibu, California, thanks to a group of surfers concerned about the escalating coastal development and the environmental threats it posed.
Since then, it evolved to become one of the most important grass-root organizations with an activist network dedicated to the safeguarding of the ocean.
The main issues this network addresses include plastic pollution, ocean protection, beach access for all, coastal preservation and clean water.
The Marine Conservation Institute was born from the vision of one person in 1996.

The organization focuses on helping the creation of a worldwide network of Blue Parks, which are recognized highly protected areas within the ocean, to ensure that the diversity and abundance of marine life will be safeguarded for future generations.
At Marine Conservation Institute, science is used to identify important marine ecosystems and advocate for their protection.
Their aim is to protect 30% of the ocean by 2030.

One of their most famous projects is the Marine Protection Atlas, a unique resource for global marine protected area information, which is constantly being updated and will be an invaluable resource for international progress in marine conservation issues.
Oceana was founded in 2001 and it became one of the largest international advocacy organizations focused specifically on ocean conservation.
Their offices, which are spread around the world, work together to create and implement strategic, directed campaigns focused on specific outcomes related to ocean biodiversity and conservation.
Their main projects focus on fighting against overfishing, reducing ocean pollution and addressing ghost fishing gear issues.
If you have spent your life in the ocean and have a vast collection of old, neoprene wetsuits in the closet, then you must check out the work of Lava Rubber.
Founded by Michael Briody, this ocean-friendly business began its recycling project in 2009.
They collect old suits or neoprene scraps from all kinds of ocean lovers, and transform them into something new!
Through a special manufacturing process, they turn the collected neoprene into what they call “Lava Rubber.
” This is a great upcycling idea, as these materials are extremely resilient and hard to get rid of.
Thanks to Lava rubber, they can have a useful new life.
On their online store, you can find all kinds of products, from slippers to outdoor mats, yoga mats, coasters and more.
Ocean Sole is another upcycling business that helps saving our ocean.
It collects washed up flip-flops found along the coastlines and beaches in Kenya.
Its founder, Julie Church got this incredible idea when she saw children making toys from discarded flip-flops.
Then, she started encouraging locals to collect, wash and cut the slippers and turning them into colorful products.
The concept was a massive success, and the best thing is that it supports local coastal communities in Kenya.
Ocean Sole does not only positively impact the lives of the local community and help the environment with the upcycling project;
its turnover further supports conservation efforts.
At Sea2See, they make glasses with recovered ocean plastic.
François van den Abeele, the company’s CEO and founder started imagining this product while working in the maritime industry, inspired by the Ocean Cleanup initiative.

His idea was creating a product that could raise awareness about ocean contamination and the importance of safeguarding marine ecosystems. After realizing that sustainability was almost none existent in the optical sector, he decided to found Sea2See, which became of the pioneers in using recycled marine polymer in the eyewear and watch sectors, and has developed a sustainable solution to reduce marine plastic and improve the lives of marginalized coastal communities.
Sea2See also collaborated with Free the Slaves to put an end to child fishing slavery: each watch you purchase will contribute to education material for marginalized children in coastal communities.
Ghost nets are fishing nets that were lost or even intentionally discarded in the ocean.
Every year, up to 1 million tons of these nets become marine debris, posing a great danger to marine animals.

Bracenet’s purpose is to recover these nets and upcycle them into new products, using the generated revenue to fund other recovery missions or donating it to projects for the protection of the oceans and marine life.
It is a great example of circular economy, where we can give value to materials that are usually considered waste, and generate positive impact.
All products are handmade and shipped without plastic;
you can find bracelets, earrings, dog leashes, bags, and much more.
This is a business model that believes in the single actions of individuals, and the fact that we can, collectively change the world!
4Ocean believes in business as a force of good and is committed to ending the ocean plastic crisis.
They run a global ocean cleanup operation with a full-time crew recovering harmful marine debris, and help educate and empower people to fight against plastic pollution.
In their online shop, they sell reusable alternatives to common single-use plastic items (like bottles and cups), cleanup kits and sustainable accessories.
Their bracelets, made with stainless steel and certified recycled 4Ocean plastic are a symbol of the fight against ocean pollution!
And, with every 4ocean product, you will also get a One Pound Promise, which ensures that one pound of trash will be pulled from the ocean, rivers, and coastlines.

content: How is human health impacted by marine plastics?
Become a member and get Oceanus magazine THE JOURNAL OF OUR OCEAN PLANET MORE TO KNOW WHOI biologist Mark Hahn discusses a recent global plastics studyÂ Â By Amy E.
NEvala | April 17, 2023 Each year, an estimated 8 million tons of bags, bottles, discarded fishing gear, and other plastic waste enters the ocean.
Itâs a problem that threatens the health of humans and marine life, and an issue that attracts the interest of a growing number of researchers worldwide.
These partnerships led WHOI senior scientists Dr.
Mark Hahn and Dr.
John Stegeman to team up with international collaborators to develop a report on ocean plastics aimed for a specific audience: the health and medical community.

This March, after more than a year of collaborative writing, Hahn, Stegeman and three dozen other authorsâincluding WHOI postdoctoral scholar Bryan James and MIT-WHOI Joint Program student Jordan Pittâcompleted the 215-page document, The Minderoo-Monaco Commission on Plastics and Human Health report.

The report, sponsored by the Australia-based Minderoo Foundation, the Centre Scientifique de Monaco, and the Prince Albert II of Monaco Foundation, was released at the Monaco Ocean Week conference this spring and subsequently was presented to the World Health Organization.

Â Hahn calls the timing of its release especially important and influential as discussions and negotiations for an international Global Plastics Treaty at the United Nations move forward in Paris this June.
Here, Hahn provides insights into the relevance of the study and how he will remain involved with ocean plastics research at WHOI.
This study attempts to pull together all of the current information on the potential impacts of plastics.

It is different from previous reports because it focuses on human impacts and is targeted at the public health and medical communities, as well as the people currently involved in the negotiations for an international treaty on plastics.

It covers not just the impacts of plastic waste but also the impacts over the complete life cycle of plastic, from extraction of the petroleum and other raw materials, through the use of plastics, to their release into the environment.
It also reviews the economic and social costs of plastics.
Dr.
Stegeman, a biochemist who studies the effects of natural and human-made pollutants on marine organisms, and I led the team that wrote the Ocean Health section.
This involved a series of discussions and writing sessions involving an international team of co-authors, which took place between March 2022 and February 2023.

One important finding is that the impacts of plastics on ocean and human health are not limited to those associated with improper disposal but involve all stages of the plastic life cycle, from extraction of the raw materials (especially petroleum), through manufacture, use, and disposal.
The impacts occur not just from the plastics themselves but also from the many chemicals that are added to the plastics.
We know that many of the chemicals released during the production of plastics or added to plastics when they are made are toxic and have been linked to a variety of diseases in people.

Many people are also concerned about the potential health impacts of exposure to microplastics and nanoplastics, the small microscopic fragments of plastic that are produced when plastics break down in the environment.
We know that people are exposed to microplastics from many sources, including from food (including seafood), drinking water, and inhalation from the air.
But the possible health impacts of that exposure are not yet well understood.
I was 12 in 1970 when the first Earth Day happened and a teenager when I read Rachel Carsonâs Silent Spring.
I think these experiences set me up to care about the health of our natural environment.
I pursued a graduate degree in toxicology from a medical school.
For my career I wanted to apply what I had learned in graduate school to the marine environment.
I came to WHOI in 1987 to work with Dr.
Stegeman.
Since then, Iâve been in a position to bridge human and environmental health fields through my interest in marine pollution and its consequences.
I lead WHOIâs Microplastics Initiative, which began in 2017 to address the presence of plastics in the marine environment.

It continues to grow as more oceanographers and ocean engineers become interested in applying their knowledge to better understand the behavior, fate, and impacts of plastics in the ocean and help identify solutions.
Iâll continue to work with my colleagues here and our collaborators around the world to do this.

The issue of plastics and their impacts on ocean and human health is complex, so I appreciate the difficulty that the negotiators face in crafting a treaty that will be effective in reducing these impacts.
Plastics provide many benefits, so the challenge is how to retain the benefits while reducing the unnecessary use of plastics and the overall impacts.
My hope is that the treaty will deal not only with the issue of plastic waste, but with the entire plastic life cycle, including production and use.

content: How Microplastics in the Ocean Will Affect Marine Life - The New York Times
Tiny bits of plastic have infiltrated the deep sea’s main food source and could alter the ocean’s role in one of Earth’s ancient cooling processes, scientists say.
Credit.
Supported by By Sabrina Imbler As long as there has been marine life, there has been marine snow — a ceaseless drizzle of death and waste sinking from the surface into the depths of the sea.
The snow begins as motes, which aggregate into dense, flocculent flakes that gradually sink and drift past the mouths (and mouth-like apparatuses) of scavengers farther down.
But even marine snow that is devoured will most likely be snowfall once more;
a squid’s guts are just a rest stop on this long passage to the deep.
Although the term may suggest wintry whites, marine snow is mostly brownish or grayish, comprising mostly dead things.
For eons, the debris has contained the same things — flecks from plant and animal carcasses, feces, mucus, dust, microbes, viruses — and transported the ocean’s carbon to be stored on the seafloor.
Increasingly, however, marine snowfall is being infiltrated by microplastics: fibers and fragments of polyamide, polyethylene and polyethylene terephthalate.
And this fauxfall appears to be altering our planet’s ancient cooling process.
Every year, tens of millions of tons of plastic enter Earth’s oceans.
Scientists initially assumed that the material was destined to float in garbage patches and gyres, but surface surveys have accounted for only about one percent of the ocean’s estimated plastic.
A recent model found that 99.
8 percent of plastic that entered the ocean since 1950 had sunk below the first few hundred feet of the ocean.
Scientists have found 10,000 times more microplastics on the seafloor than in contaminated surface waters.
Marine snow, one of the primary pathways connecting the surface and the deep, appears to be helping the plastics sink.
And scientists have only begun to untangle how these materials interfere with deep-sea food webs and the ocean’s natural carbon cycles.
“It’s not just that marine snow transports plastics or aggregates with plastic,” Luisa Galgani, a researcher at Florida Atlantic University, said.
“It’s that they can help each other get to the deep ocean.
” The sunlit surface of the sea blooms with phytoplankton, zooplankton, algae, bacteria and other minuscule life, all feeding on sunbeams or one another.

As these microbes metabolize, some produce polysaccharides that can form a sticky gel that attracts the lifeless bodies of tiny organisms, small shreds of larger carcasses, shells from foraminifera and pteropods, sand and microplastics, which stick together to form larger flakes.
“They are the glue that keeps together all the components of marine snow,” Dr.
Galgani said.
Marine snowflakes fall at different rates.
Smaller ones have a more languid descent — “as slow as a meter a day,” said Anela Choy, a biological oceanographer at Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, San Diego.
Bigger particles, such as dense fecal pellets, can sink quicker.
“It just skyrockets to the bottom of the ocean,” said Tracy Mincer, a researcher at Florida Atlantic University.
Plastic in the ocean is constantly being degraded;
even something as big and buoyant as a milk jug will eventually shed and splinter into microplastics.

These plastics develop biofilms of distinct microbial communities — the “plastisphere,” said Linda Amaral-Zettler, a scientist at the Royal Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, who coined the term.
“We sort of think about plastic as being inert,” Dr.
Amaral-Zettler said.
“Once it enters the environment, it’s rapidly colonized by microbes.
” Microplastics can host so many microbial hitchhikers that they counteract the natural buoyancy of the plastic, causing their raft to sink.
But if the biofilms then degrade on the way down, the plastic could float back up, potentially leading to a yo-yoing purgatory of microplastics in the water column.
Marine snow is anything but stable;
as flakes free-fall into the abyss, they are constantly congealing and falling apart, rent by waves or predators.
“It’s not as simple as: Everything’s falling all the time,” said Adam Porter, a marine ecologist at the University of Exeter in England.
“It’s a black box in the middle of the ocean, because we can’t stay down there long enough to work out what’s going on.
” To explore how marine snow and plastics are distributed in the water column, Dr.
Mincer has begun to sample deeper waters with a dishwasher-size pump full of filters that dangles on a wire from a research boat.
The filters are arranged from big mesh to small to filter out fish and plankton.
Running these pumps for 10 hours at a stretch has revealed nylon fibers and other microplastics distributed throughout the water column below the South Atlantic subtropical gyre.
But even with a research boat and its expensive and unwieldy equipment, an individual piece of marine snow is not easily retrieved from deep water in the actual ocean.
The pumps often disturb the snow and scatter fecal pellets.

And the flakes alone offer little insight into how fast some snows are sinking, which is vital to understanding how long the plastics linger, yo-yo or sink in the water column before settling on the seafloor.
“Is it decades?
” Dr.
Mincer asked.
“Is it hundreds of years?
Then we can understand what we’re in here for, and what kind of problem this really is.
” To answer these questions, and work within a budget, some scientists have made and manipulated their own marine snow in the lab.
In Exeter, Dr.
Porter collected buckets of seawater from a nearby estuary and loaded the water into continuously rolling bottles.
He then sprinkled in microplastics, including polyethylene beads and polypropylene fibers.
The constant churning, and a squirt of sticky hyaluronic acid, encouraged particles to collide and stick together into snow.
“We obviously don’t have 300 meters of a tube to make it sink,” Dr.
Porter said.
“By rolling it, what you’re doing is you’re creating a never-ending water column for the particles to fall through.
” After the bottles rolled for three days, he pipetted out the snow and analyzed the number of microplastics in each flake.

His team found that every type of microplastic they tested aggregated into marine snow, and that microplastics such as polypropylene and polyethylene — normally too buoyant to sink on their own — readily sank once incorporated into marine snow.
And all the marine snow contaminated with microplastics sank significantly faster than the natural marine snow.
Dr.

Porter suggested that this potential change of the speed of the snow could have vast implications for how the ocean captures and stores carbon: Faster snowfalls could store more microplastics in the deep ocean, whereas slower snowfalls could make the plastic-laden particles more available to predators, potentially starving food webs deeper down.
“The plastics are a diet pill for these animals,” said Karin Kvale, a carbon cycle scientist at GNS Science in New Zealand.
In experiments in Crete, with funding from the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research program, Dr.
Galgani has tried mimicking marine snow on a larger scale.
She dropped six mesocosms — huge bags that each contained nearly 800 gallons of seawater and recreated natural water movement — in a large pool.
Under these conditions, marine snow formed.
“In the field, you mostly make observations,” Dr.
Galgani said.
“You have so little space and a limited system.
In the mesocosm, you are manipulating a natural system.
” Dr.
Galgani mixed microplastics into three mesocosms in an attempt to “recreate a sea and maybe a future ocean where you can have a high concentration of plastic,” she said.
The mesocosms laden with microplastics produced not just more marine snow but also more organic carbon, as the plastics offered more surfaces for microbes to colonize.
All this could seed the deep ocean with even more carbon and alter the ocean’s biological pump, which helps regulate the climate.
“Of course, it’s a very, very big picture,” Dr.
Galgani said.
“But we have some signals that it can have an effect.
Of course, it depends on how much plastic there is.
” To understand how microplastics might travel through deep-sea food webs, some scientists have turned to creatures for clues.
Every 24 hours, many species of marine organism embark on a synchronized migration up and down in the water column.
“They do the equivalent of a marathon every day and night,” Dr.
Choy said.
Guilherme V.
B.
Ferreira, a researcher at the Rural Federal University of Pernambuco in Brazil, wondered: “Is it possible they are transporting the plastics up and down?
” Dr.
Ferreira and Anne Justino, a doctoral student at the same university, collected vampire squids and midwater squids from a patch of the tropical Atlantic.
They found a plethora of plastics in both species: mostly fibers, but also fragments and beads.
This made sense for midwater squids, which migrate toward the surface at night to feed on fish and copepods that eat microplastics directly.
But vampire squids, which live in deeper waters with fewer microplastics, had even higher levels of plastic, as well as foam, in their stomachs.
The researchers hypothesize that the vampire squids’ primary diet of marine snow, especially meatier fecal pellets, may be funneling plastics into their bellies.
“It’s very concerning,” Ms.
Justino said.
Dr.
Ferreira said: “They are one of the most vulnerable species for this anthropogenic influence.
” Ms.
Justino has excavated fibers and beads from the digestive tracts of lanternfish, hatchetfish and other fish that migrate up and down in the mesopelagic, 650 to 3,300 feet down.
Some microbial communities that settle on microplastics can bioluminesce, drawing in fish like a lure, said Dr.
Mincer.
In the Monterey Bay Canyon, Dr.
Choy wanted to understand if certain species of filter feeders were ingesting microplastics and transporting them into food webs in deeper water.
“Marine snow is one of the major things that connects food webs across the ocean,” she said.
Dr.
Choy zeroed in on the giant larvacean Bathochordaeus stygius.
The larvacean resembles a tiny tadpole and lives inside a palatial bubble of mucus that can reach up to a meter long.
“It’s worse than the grossest booger you’ve ever seen,” Dr.
Choy said.
When their snot-houses become clogged from feeding, the larvaceans move out and the heavy bubbles sink.
Dr.
Choy found that these palaces of mucus are crowded with microplastics, which are funneled to the deep along with all their carbon.
Giant larvaceans are found across the world’s oceans, but Dr.
Choy emphasized that her work was focused on the Monterey Bay Canyon, which belongs to a network of marine protected areas and is not representative of other, more polluted seas.
“It’s one deep bay on one coast of one country,” Dr.
Choy said.
“Scale up and think about how vast the ocean is, especially the deep water.
” Individual flakes of marine snow are small, but they add up.
A model created by Dr.
Kvale estimated that in 2010, the world’s oceans produced 340 quadrillion aggregates of marine snow, which could transport as many as 463,000 tons of microplastics to the seafloor each year.
Scientists are still exploring exactly how this plastic snow is sinking, but they do know for sure, Dr.
Porter said, that “everything eventually sinks in the ocean.
” Vampire squids will live and die and eventually become marine snow.
But the microplastics that pass through them will remain, eventually settling on the seafloor in a stratigraphic layer that will mark our time on the planet long after humans are gone.
